values:
Name: Buckety Wilson

Title/Alias: Buckety, Buckwheat, Chop

Appearance: Bucket is a mid-height young lady who prefers ankle-length black dresses and similar clothing, as well as having a rather large collection of hats, ranging from a nice stetson to a favored black beret. She has the obvious features of a Pacific native, with puffy cheeks, weak chin, and dark hair. She has a tendency to wear charm bracelets and necklaces made of keys.

Personality: Usually a friendly, open person, Buckety enjoys eating, riding around in the gang's van, smiling, reading manga, collecting keys, and breaking bottles behind the 7-Eleven. She's a good mood kind of person, but doesn't try to butt in on people or force their attitude. Her friends say that she used to have no bed at all, but that now that she has one, she always seems to get up on the right side.

The Word: Buckety is a street kid who is nominally a member of a gang of troublemakers with seemingly no direction in life other than busting into construction sites and hanging around alleys; not good or smart enough to hit college and just smart enough to be trouble, Buckety makes a nuisance of herself in various places downtown.

Character Sheet - Private
Protip: Do not read if you're in Iceman's game or really curious. Or awesome. Awesome people read below, too.

Desired power: I really have no idea in this regard. A superpower is supposed to go here. I thought key-kinesis could be cool.

Skills: Buckety considers herself a poet, but isn't all that great at it, and is much better at picking locks and fiddling with “gizmos,” and given a roll of duct tape, a multitool, and time, can fix just about anything, it just won't be very pretty, having picked up the skill when needing to repair clothes, just about everything in the squats, and, well, not having a key to the squats (which led to her penchant of collecting keys, in the case at least one of them goes to something). She is also a good cook, but this mostly comes from her skill at commodifying and an instinctive grasp of what sorts of cheap foods go well together when thrown into the same pot rather than anything resembling a gourmet.

Flaws: Buckety has a rather plump fear of abandonment that comes from her absentee father and her nearly absentee mother. She has trouble remembering the woman's name and while she knows intellectually it was due to stress and a need to work, she still hasn't forgiven her mother for being practically nonexistent through her childhood, though this fact is more subconscious than anything in the forefront of her thoughts. After garnering a reputation in the first two years of high school for being easy, Buckety backed off from her relationships for fear of turning into her mother and has since become rather frigid in regards to relationships beyond a platonic level.

Background: Buckety's mom was somebody's powwow snag, and she never knew either of her parents a great deal, being in and out of the NAYA Family Center most of the day, taking advantage of whatever programs for food and companionship, at least from the age of thirteen on. Until then, her mother left for large portions of the day, and she was left to fend mostly for herself; her solution to the lack of parental contact was to make friends and spend as much time with them as possible. While she never had many friends at one time, the few she's kept have helped her through most of her life without too much psychological trauma. However, most of her friends are into the idea of being street kids, even though the majority of them are middle class, but they do it well most of the time.

Defining Incident: For a long time Buckety was one of those gloomy kids who liked to try being edgy and really ended up just being rather annoying. She lamented her mom's neglect of her, and tried her hand at some rather dark poetry. Then she hooked up with Sarah. Sarah was a big sister in the NAYA Family Center outreach program, and since the two had “similar interests,” namely, being moody and shopping at the Hot Topic, the Center put the two of them together. Sarah was from a higher income bracket and was helping out at the Center under her father's supervision, and blamed her parents for the life she led, and felt disenfranchised with pretty much everything. They met for a period of about six months, with Buckety questioning even her own mood as she saw Sarah's comparatively posh life. Eventually, Sarah stopped coming to the meetings, and when she finally caught word some weeks later that Sarah and her boyfriend had a suicide pact that only Sarah followed up on, with her boyfriend injured and in therapy. It took Buckety several days to actually parse the incident, and the whole affair made her decide that her own behavior had been somewhat pathetic.

Statement of Self: “There is no greater treasure than friendship. Let's be a pirate crew!” (this is supposed to be a quote that sums up the character somehow. I have no idea what is it this thing am make go).

NPC's of Importance:

Victor: Buckety's first real friend is still her friend. The two met in preschool and remained pretty much inseparable until their early teen years and hormones kicked in. After determining that any measure of non-platonic relationship was “weird,” Buckety and Victor just went back to being friends. His parents are mildly eccentric new age middle-class suburbanites who still put forth the token canard that Buckety's a bad influence on Victor, even though he's the surly one of the two. In spite of this, or because of it, Victor's idea of rebellion against his vegan parents is eating at fast food restaurants and wearing clothes he bought from a mall rather than the thrift store. Victor enjoys getting into fights, pretending his family is poor, hanging out with Buckety, spending time alone behind buildings with his girlfriend Carrie, and setting stuff in buckets on fire.
 "HEY VICTOR!" ha I still get a kick out of it.

Carrie: A granola girl who wears her own hand made clothing and smells of soy milk and almonds, Carrie adores pink and eggshell white, and is Victor's girlfriend. Her mom burned to death in a house fire when she was six and playing with matches, and she still has the scars on her upper left arm where she was burned, too, and has a fascination with watching Victor set controlled fire to things, since she won't touch anything resembling a lighter herself. She believes that recycling will save the Earth and likes playing the guitar, giggling uncontrollably, adjusting her glasses, and listening to rhythm-less Native chanting. It's also likely that she feels uncomfortable when she's not complaining about something, and so finances a lot of the group's expeditions to places she can complain about, such as hamburger joints, gas stations, low-income neighborhoods, and junk stores.

Scoob: A slightly overweight young man with a collection of dirty white Hello Kitty shirts, torn jeans, and a blonde soul patch, Scoob is never without his giant slurpee cup. He maintains The Van, which is sort of a white, beat up hunk of metal that's peeling rust so bad on the roof it looks like autumn leaves that the gang spends most of the time in. He's covered the seats in beads and hung one of Bomber's dreamcatchers in the rear view, and plans to paint “a really cool scene with like wolves and a full moon and maybe some Indian babes and a totem pole” on it. Once he gets the paint, the airbrushes, and the art skill. Scoob's greatest ambition is to be an obscure cult musician, once he gets around to learning to play the guitar.

Bomber: Nobody knows his real name, but it's probably something like “Jet” or “Mack” or something, but they all call him Bomber; he used to wear a bomber jacket, with a white fur collar and everything, covered in buttons and safety pins. At least until, as he claimed, the look got “too mainstream.” Bomber is laid back, has a droning voice, and considers himself a smooth operator but just comes off as being lazy. He's tried to get into both Carrie and Buckety's pants once or twice, but Buckety's issues combined with his gangly frame and penchant for smelling like cigarette smoke prevented anything from really happening. He splits his time between sleeping in the van, making dreamcatchers, and trying to score, achieving marginal success in all things.

Atheism is hardcore.

To say that a supernatural entity, let's say, for example, the God of Abraham, but we could be talking Allah or Thor or His Eminence the Grand Explodo, does not exist period, is to take a great a leap of faith as to say that such a being exists, because who are you as a three-dimensional being to know in our (at minimum) four dimensional universe if anyone or anything is out there or not? Thankfully, this is not atheism. Atheism can be this, but more precisely, atheism is the profession of not believing in believing in something, rather than an outright rejection of the same.

"But wait, that's agnosticism," you say.

Well, you'd be right. And wrong.

Atheism, literally taken, means "without faith," that is, professing no faith, and not simply deciding one way or another that a god exists. Saying "I don't believe in god" is not an admission that there is no god, simply that the speaker doesn't believe in a supernatural deity. There's no need to reject anything outright, simply a need to not pick it up in the first place. It's not like you're not checking, however. I know that if I found out such a being existed (or they; could be several beings), I'd sure as heck worship it if that's what it wanted (after all, it has absolute, unflinching control over this reality, not unlike a dictator that cannot be rebelled against). Unfortunately, this evidence can't show up unless said entity shows up and asks how everything is going and if we'd like a little more miracle, maybe some fire from the heavens, or a nice rain of bread or something.

Atheism does have a requirement, though, mostly that you take the universe with a grain of salt. After all, the universe has people in it, and a lot of them are assholes who need a giant father figure ready with the fire and brimstone if they act up. They'll ask you where you get your morals from, and you should reply with a thank you that they acknowledged that you have morals. Shoot 'em back: ask 'em why they need the threat of eternal torment to be nice people, and they can't just be nice on their own. It scares the crap out of 'em to know that someone doesn't need to have a security camera burnin' a hole in their back to be nice.

Anyway, let's go back to the God of Abraham. According to our good friend the Bible, this guy loved him some miracles. He'd miracle left and right all over the place. There was fire from heaven, giant pillars of fire, rain of bread, removing demons, and smiting. Lots of smiting. An unbelievable amount of smiting. Nowadays, you don't see that. Where is it at? The guy who used to lay all manner of divine smackdown all over the blessed place can't be bothered to do more than make someone shiver or blabber incoherently or make swamp kinfolk hold rattlesnakes?

The human smile is a mystery to me.

Are you happy?
Are you being malicious and sneaky?
Did you just hear a joke?
Are you having a good day?

If I ask these questions, I'm avoided, I assume because I'm seen as a freak, or that I'm somehow in the same league as the man screaming "no" on the street corner. The fact, however, remains that I can not read a smile. I am literally incapable of telling where a smile originates, why people do it, and when I should also do this. As a result, if a situation occurs where I should smile, I often do not, since I simply don't recognize when I'm supposed to.

The same can be applied to almost any situation; the neurotypical mind automatically checks for body language on a subconscious level, and when someone doesn't display those all-important indicators, they are "creepy" on some fundamental, perhaps even unknown level. I've been told I'm a disturbing individual, that I bother people, and in a few cases, have been asked to leave because I don't have those same responses (in fact, an occurrence earlier today has prompted me to write this). The same however, happens when I look at other people. As much as I don't have properly discernible body language, everyone else's body language is equally mysterious and disturbing to me. My attempts to emulate it result in inorganic, jerky, spastic, or improper movements that I can assume only adds to the discomfort of others.

I can now, so many years later, keep track of body language, but I have to do it consciously. This is one of the reasons I got into art. I could pretend to be normal, and under that pretense, I could learn "code words" to assign to different modes of the body's expression. I didn't get much art-wise out of it (I'm still struggling with art after all these years), but I did learn through books on anatomy and position how to decode the mysteries of human posture and body language. However, I can't keep track of more than maybe four people at a time. Any more than that and I freeze up, my mask drops, and I start acting like an emotionless robot. That isn't to say I'm devoid of emotion, far from it, in fact, that my emotions are wired to completely different stressors and stimuli from a neurotypical is another point against me. If someone close to me dies, I simply shrug and assume that means I won't be able to talk to them again, but heaven help me if I have to go to a gas station I've never been to before, or if the phone rings and I'm not expecting a call, or if my printer runs out of ink and I don't have a replacement cartridge. Can you imagine being around someone who doesn't bat an eye at a car accident but throws a tantrum if the soda machine doesn't work the way it's supposed to? I know that's disturbing to some people, but on my side, I can't imagine why anyone not involved in the accident itself would be interested in its outcome. I have to force myself to react the way everyone else does.

When I was a child, this made it difficult to make friends; I can still count the amount of friends I have on one hand, and the ones I have now outnumber the ones I've had in my entire childhood.

I feel like that kid from A.I., capable of emotion but incapable of knowing how to process that emotion, and so thrown to the wayside and forgotten by the world. It's hard to be the one who really is on the outside, absolutely confused as to normal, everyday interaction, so much so that going to the grocery store is like facing every childhood fear every single time you go.

I just wish I could make people understand that I'm not crazy or a robot or an alien or something.

shock, really. http://www.motherjones.com/news/feature/2007/09/school_of_shock.html Seems like it's old news and it's just getting to me down the pipeline. Ah, well, such is life. I'm glad I didn't get sent here. Attempting to shock autism out of someone is tantamount to trying to shock them out of a citrus allergy or the fact that they have eyes: it's how the brain is wired, not something you can fix with some 19th-century therapy. I'm working on the final draft of Bubble right now; it's all minor edits, though. It should be done even before the 1st (heck, hopefully it'll be done today).

I once read a reference to this in a list of notable films and television shows that make reference to Lovecraft's work. The writer didn't like this one very much, and so I didn't pursue it, until I came across it earlier today. Now, here it is..... The Collect Call of Cathulhu. That writer was obviously no nerd (though the writer of this show is... it's J. Michael Straczynski!). This is absolutely awesome in so many ways I cannot begin to fathom. It's, well, indescribably. They go to Miskatonic University, their NPC for this adventure casts a spell and loses sanity (she faints), and lots of Lovecraft lingo being thrown around. The professor's lack of extreme terror at the shoggoth tells me she's seen them before.... Notable fun quotes: "He makes Gozer look like Little Mary Sunshine." "A guy that looks like Godzilla with a squid hat on can't be hard to find."

You just know America's gonna want some of this..... America: "Hey! Swiss! Get your grubby gnomish hands out of that innocent country!" Swiss: "What you say?" Liechtenstein: "Nah, guys, it's cool, see......" Korea: "HAY GUYS LOOK AT OUR NUKES" America: "Shut up! This is between us and the clockmaker!"

I just spent $13.72 to reclaim a small piece of my childhood.

That's right, Escape to Witch Mountain and Return from Witch Mountain just came out on a one-disc DVD.

It's a very strange thing, to see those films again, to know, again, how bad they were. I knew they were bad back then, too, and I didn't - and still don't - care. It's a piece of me for sale at Wal-Mart on the new bargain releases shelf near the impulse-buy section, and that's all that really matters.

Read a book called Thinking in Pictures. It's spurred me to sit down and actually think about how I, as an Asperger's-type autistic, recall and store information. It is a good good book, very helpful to me. I also picked up one of them flash memory sticks, a 256MB thing. It stores much of my writing on it now. Gaia's Summer, chapter 12, approaches completion. It's about 2/3 done as of this update. Chapter 11 gave me the underworld, but 12 is being much friendlier, though still problematic. After I finish it, I'm off to update chapters 1-10 with changes my friendly neighborhood editor has suggested. Still haven't heard back from the agent about Gaia's Bubble. This is a very, very good thing. Titles for the next two books are finalized, and they have plot summaries.

Alrighty. So, I've finished the Chapter 6 draft. I've noted some errors, but I'm not going to really fix them until I drop them off with my editor and get them returned to me next Friday. I guess one of the big problems for me is that I'm afraid of continuity errors in this monster. I have to meticulously go back through everything to check and re-check for what I'm setting up for later and if it's being set up successfully, and I really hate doing that because then I see things I don't need to change or fix.

Oh well, right? What's written is written, and only what needs to be changed should be altered.
Sector one of Gaia's Summer is complete. And by that, I mean the text for chapters 01-05. Chapter 06 begins today, as well.

Wow, I'm really stressin' today. That's it.

What? Thought I was gonna rant for three paragraphs? Nah. I said I was gonna try and cut down on that.

Gaia Cycle, book two. In Production title: Gaia's Summer. Basic outline complete. Test scenes complete. Dialogue explorations complete. Metaplot thread notes complete. Text percentage complete: 6% Everything's going pretty smoothly. Chapter 2 gave me a few hiccups, but that's because there's fighting going on, and that's my weak point. The next eight chapters are all character development, so those should be pretty simple to get done with. Chapter 2 is done, though. That means for the next six chapters I'll b eswitching gears completely and handing off perspective to the team sent to Berelen to investigate three things. I don't expect to work for two years on this one, thank whatever non-denominational entities that may or may not exist depending on your personal belief system.

Okay, so, Gaia's Bubble goes into the mail today. Here's crossing my fingers and hoping I don't have to find another agent, or at least, this one can point me in the right direction. Outline and Chapter 1 of Gaia's Summer has been completed. It looks to be 35 chapters all told, about 1.4 times the length of Gaia's Bubble. I may have some minor issues with this one, being that it's mostly urban in nature, but that should be alright. I may walk around downtown every so often, just to get a feel.

I'm currently going back over Gaia's Bubble, chapters one through eleven, and coming to some realizations. The writing sucks. Not too surprising, I wrote them two years ago, and it's been my experience that my writing skill dramatically improves at an intense rate, nowhere near as fast as my art skill (I wish my art skill improved as fast). No worries, though, I'm not starting over. Just some tightening up is all I need to do. Occurences of the word "it," for example. I want those out of there. "It" doesn't describe anything (I don't want to fall into Lovecraft's pit of "indescribable aeon-dead protomasses"). I don't even like using the word "its," but I do. The good part of all this is that I can see most of the mistakes easily, and tie them up. Once this is done (hopefully by Saturday), I can drop this mother fucker in the mail to some agents. I've got one avenue, at least: my mom kicks so much ass it's hard to describe. It's like, imagine a cyborg made entirely out of diamonds that looks like a hot chick with the ability to fire lasers from its eyes that cause Nazis to spontaneously freeze to death, and fights through a horde space robot cyborg zombies just to get its morning pop tarts. My mom kicks more ass than that. Her book is on Amazon now; she says she'll be getting proofs in real soon. She's promised t help out a lot with the whole agent process, which is good, because my head hurts just thinking about it.

So, like, I promised I wouldn't rant, but I have before. I'm gonna try real hard not to in the future, though. No promises. Anyway, novel finished. All done. Currently, it is teh suck, but I have been going back over chapters, and there's a few things that need fixing: appearances of the word "it," some choppy dialogue errors, a few editing splices, and Bea's magically transforming duffel-to-sea-bag. Right, so, everything's pretty much done. Book two, Gaia's Summer, has a summary written, and now I'm doing chapter treatments while I tighten up Gaia's Bubble and lay the groundwork for book three, Gaia's Sword. The groundwork of the plot for the rest of the books (of which there are bunches) has been laid, and I have quick synopses of all of them. After these first three "Gaia" books, there will be going back in time four thousand years to the Magitech War to check up on a band of wacky mercenaries and their amusing hijinks trying to run away from formless terror from beyond space. Then I'll check back in with Bea and her new job as a waitress for a small town, and see how long that lasts before the whole being a hero thing catches up. It'll be fun, I promise.

Novel Completion Progress Update Force Team Go!

Text Completion: 100% (w00t!)

Final Check: 53%
It's been very long. Short update. Novel Progress: 70.8% Novel-related artwork.

FOX presents the true story of one young man's fight against his lack of legs. He wanted to bowl, and the world told him no...... 
But he didn't let that stop him......

"I'll teach you to keep me out!" (sound of shotgun cocking) "I'm comin' for ya!"

He'll hunt down the anthropomorphic supernatural force behind his suffering and BLOW IT AWAY! This fall on FOX.

http://poetry.rotten.com/bowlerplegic/

Check it. My cat kicks all cat asses from here to Aberdeen. Heck, that's so much ass, I don't even know where Aberdeen is. Oh, wait, I do. It's on Aesca, yo. My cat kicks so much ass she kicks your ass to places that don't even exist, man. Ohhhh, damn! Special update! I'm out of milk! That's right, you amateurs, I'm out of milk! Tremble at my feet. Also, I'm trying to get this damn novel out the door, so's I can hurry up and put out some world material, perhaps for use in gamin'. In RPGs. And such.

I just bought a new cat toy. It consist of a brilliantly colored ball of fluff on the end of a string. Apparently, she thinks this is the most exciting and fantastic thing in the world, and wishes to take it under my bed. Sadly, the fluff-ball-string contraption goes nowhere, for it is affixed to the side of my bookshelf. Here are some little-known facts about my cat.
  • My cat once jumped from the kitchen counter to the back of the couch in one tremendous leap.
  • My cat is small sized. As a small creature, she gets a +1 size bonus to her Armor Class and attack rolls, and a +4 size modifier to Hide checks.
  • My cat is responsible for the re-election of George W. Bush. Shame on my kitty!
  • Low Light Vision: Freya can see twice as far as a human in starlight or torchlight. At night during a full moon, my cat can function just fine.
  • My cat once fought Jackie Chan to a standstill and stole from him the Armor of Eternity.
  • If my cat holds her sword aloft and shouts "The Power is Mine!' four times, she becomes Queen Destructica, savior of the world of Halcyonia.

I don't rant about stuff. So, no ranting. Just gonna say that I'm a bit dissapointed in America, and the I think we're too quick to forget that we're a global community (i.e. we're not the only or most important country on Earth). Anyway, enough about that. Nobody wants to dwell on that crap for too long. I know nobody gives a shit, but I got a whole 7 paragraphs done today. Got a good opening sentence out, too. Check this stuff. "A thousand shredded suns danced against unseemly pitch, their cacophonous roar killed by silence that dwelt between endless reaches of dead-cold where nothing moved or echoed." And check it, lame sketch day, an elven bladesinger.

...the ride of the internet tough guy. Also, a prick. Watch as his logic is attacked and he calls people sheep, then calls those who insult him cowards. Watch as others try to engage in intellectual conversation with him and are attacked or ignored. Watch as he finally, at long last, threatens those who tell him his little, self-imposed "mature" world might not be all it's cracked up to be (and holds onto his "mature" comment) - oh, and he aparrently can't be bothered to even look up the basic tenets of his religion, either. Religioustolerance.org has some very interesting things to say about Asatru, and he appears to fit not much of it. Viking fanboy syndrome, I think.

Always wondered how well an alien is science fiction approximates aliens? Well, wonder no more. Now with the Adam J. Thaxton alien scale, you can tell at a glance how alien something is! As you can see, Spock is a 2. Most of Star Trek runs from 1-3. Star Wars runs from 1-7, based upon some of the creatures from the novels. Most of it is 1-4, however. Pick up Expedition by Wayne Barlowe for some good solid 9. Here's how to read the chart: 1 means it looks just like a human. Fucking Stargate. 2 is a Bajoran/Klingon/Vulcan type alien, with rubber appliances attached to a human actor. 3 is the Cardassians, the Jem'Hadar, or the Unas. THese things took time and effort in makeup. 4 is for aliens that are humanoid but may be created with other effect techniques, i.e., the Asgard from Stargate. 5 is an alien that looks just like a terrestrial creature, except it's bigger/smarter/etc. 6 is a terrestrial creature with appliances or an easy fix i.e. it's like a lobster but with 20 legs and spider fangs. 7 is a creature not like a terrestrial creature but is a predator/parasite or what have you that feeds exclusively on a terrestrial creature. 8 is an alien like Giger's - it's specific, but not so much, and is only vaguely humanoid or recognizable. It may be impossible and/or implausible, but still very cool. 9 is....well..... HOLY JESUS FUCK, IT'S AN ALIEN

I saw the most wonderful sunset today.

A red-orange sun dripped below a layer of salmon scales awash with orange and red that calmly receded into a royal purple as it curled about the sanguine edges of those lower clouds. Clouds like castle parapets above were awash in fire, a deep and burning crimson shattered by puffs of curled orange vapor that held solidly onto the sky. Beams of yellow split above the integral sky, gradually fading into the blue-purple of their surroundings, the golden outline visible until it arced above my head.

Stupid Jeanne may mess this up, though. I get stressed by abnormalities in my schedule very easily, and have been unable to actually work since the hurricanes came by. Means I'm in financial trouble at the moment. No money means no food fix. Anyway, I've finally been able to get some good work done; it's all good, though. I'm told that I've managed in less than a year to get to a place most authors take five years to get to. I'm happy with my synopsis, I'm happy with my characters and their portrayals. Heck, I'm even happy with the side of Bea that shows through to her friends. I am perfectly good with getting some work done today. I'm feeling much better for it. Watch Avalon. Mamoru Oshii's the director, film was made in 2001 with Polish actors. Kicks the ass off The Matrix for cinematography and philosophy. Oh yeah, watch the subtitled version! The dub actors suck ass and the synch rate is terrible. Also, they felt the need to add in narration for some odd reason. Of course there's long streches of silence.....it's a movie, a visual medium. Watch the images. And love them.

It's the seventh day of the week, you know.

Saturnday. Saturday. Astruyad.

There are ants in my apartment.

I put tape on the walls.

          It isn't like

i had to.
I was in it. It passed by. Life is normal again. Drawn during the storm by candle light.
Still no comic, but now Bea is in color! w00t!

Tomorrow maybe. For today, a sketch. This is the character Yakkorat tells me will come back and kill me one day, what with all the hell I put her through. __________________________________ (rest of entry removed because it was teh suck)
There it is. Been going slow.
Bea returns to speak with Judas Cohdroy in a comic inspired by Five For Fighting's "100 Years." This is page one. Seven pages in all.

I need 'em like some people need food or water. I used to remember watching this one particular show when I went over to my grandma's. I remember I loved it. It had some kids, a flying golden bird, and a real catchy opening tune, and they were looking for these cities for some reason and I don't remember why....anyway, I forgot the name of the show. Thankfully, the internet is full of obscure and bizarre things. The Mysterious Cities of Gold....now, if only I could find some episodes and the money to buy them with. There's another show I remember, and I remember even less of it. I remember the avatar, Arkana. She was always talking about Arkadia and how it was in deep shit all the time. Anyway, it has several names. It's known as Spartakus and the Sun Beneath the Sea mostly, though. I also need episodes of this, dammit.

The novel, it is getting progress. Each time I start working on it, I feel the urge to restart it, so yesterday, I did. Chapter 2 and Chapter 6 stay intact, as do the "Memories" segments for the most part. However, there are now going to be a total of 12 chapters (making Chapter 6 actually Chapter 12).
I am very upset that I have been unable to work for quite some time. I have a grocery store scene that needs done and an opening chapter what needs revising.

I had a KICK-ASS weekend.

My car battery DIED, then I sat in the 95 degree heat waiting for a jump....my milk spoiled during this time.

I finally got home, my AIR CONDITIONER WAS BROKEN and I had to sleep in the 86 DEGREE room.

It was AWESOME!
